editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Fletcher, John, 1579-1625.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Flourish. Enter astorax King of Paphos, his sister Calis, train, and Cleanthe, Lucippe gentlewomen at one door; at the other Eumenes a soldier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Health to my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Eumenes, welcome:
Welcome to Paphos soldier to our love,
And that fair health ye wish us through the camp
May it disperse itself, and make all happy;
How does the general, the valiant Memnon,
And how his wars, Eumenes?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: The gods have given you (Royal sir) a soldier
Better never sought a danger, more approved
In way of war, more master of his fortunes,
Expert in leading 'em; in doing valiant,
In following all his deeds to victories,
And holding fortune certain there.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O soldier,
Thou speak'st a man indeed; a general general,
A soul conceived a soldier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ten set battles
Against the strong usurper Diocles
Whom long experience had begotten a leader
Ambition raised too mighty: hath your Memnon
Won, and won gloriously, distressed and shook him
Even from the head of all his hopes to nothing:
In three he beat the thunderbolt his brother
Forced him to wall himself up: there not safe,
Shook him with warlike engines like an earthquake,
Till like a snail he left his shell and crawled
By night, and hideous darkness to destruction:
Disarmed for ever rising more; twelve castles,
Some though impregnable; towns twice as many
Countries that like the wind knew no command
But savage wildness; hath this general
With loss of blood and youth, through storms and tempests
Called to your fair obedience. Drum within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O my soldier
That thou wert now within my arms; what drums -Drum
Are those that beat Eumenes?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: His my sovereign;
Himself i'th head of conquest drawing home,
An old man now to offer up his glories,
And endless conquest at your shrine,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go all,
And entertain him with all ceremony,
We'll keep him now a courtier.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sir, a strange one,
Pray God his language bear it; by my life, sir
He knows no compliment, nor curious casting
Of words into fit places ere he speak 'em,
He can say fight well fellow, and I'll thank thee:
He that must eat, must sweat; bring up the rear there,
Or charge that wing of horse home. Flourish.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go too, go too. Ent. Memnon and a train of courtiers and soldiers, two captains, Chilax.
Valiant and wise are twins sir: welcome, welcome,
Welcome my fortunate and famous general,
High in thy prince's favour as in fame,
Welcome to peace and Paphos.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thank your grace,
And would to God my dull tongue had that sweetness
To thank you as I should; but pardon me,
My sword and I speak roughly sir: your battles
I dare well say, I have fought well; for I bring ye
That lazy end you wish for peace, so fully,
That no more name of war is: who now thinks
Sooner or safer these might have been ended.
Begin 'em if ye dare again; I'll thank him.
Soldier and soldier's mate these twenty five years,
At length your general, (As one whose merit
Durst look upon no less,) I have waded through
Dangers would damned these soft souls, but to hear of
The maidenheads of thousand lives hangs here sir,
Since which time, prince, I know no court but martial,
No oily language, but the shock of arms,
No dalliance but with death; no lofty measures
But weary and sad marches, cold and hunger,
Larums at midnight, valour's self would shake at,
Yet I never shrunk. Balls of consuming wildfire,
That licked men up like lightning, have I laughed at,
And tossed 'em back again like children's trifles
Upon the edges of my enemy's swords
I have marched like whirlwinds, fury at this hand waiting,
Death at my right; fortune my forlorn hope,
When I have grappled with destruction,
And tugged with pale faced ruin, night and mischief,
Frighted to see a new day break in blood,
And everywhere I conquered; and for you sir,
Mother's have wanted wombs to make me famous,
And blown ambition dangers; those that grieved ye,
I have taken order for i'th' earth: those fools
That shall hereafter.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No more wars my soldier:K. takes Mem. aside and talks with him.
We must now treat of peace sir.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How he talks,
How gloriously.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A goodly timbered fellow,
Valiant no doubt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If valour dwell in vaunting;
In what a phrase he speaks as if his actions
Could be set of in nothing but a noise,
Sure has a drum in's mouth.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I wonder wenches
How he would speak to us.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Nothing but alarm
Tell us whose throat he cut, show us his sword,
And bless it for sure biting.

sp.speaker: Lucippe.
sp.l: And t like your grace,
I do not think he knows us what we are,
Or to what end; for I have heard his followers
Affirm he never saw a woman that exceeded
A sutler's wife yet, or in execution
Old bedrid beldames without teeth or tongues,
That would not fly his fury? how he looks.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: This way devoutly.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: Sure his lordship's viewing
Our fortifications.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: If he mount at me,
I may chance choke his battery.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Still his eye
Keeps quarter this way: Venus grant his valour
Be not in love.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: If he be, presently
Expect a herald and a trumpet with ye
To bid ye render; we two perdu's pay for't else.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'll leave ye to my sister, and these ladies
To make your welcome fuller: my good soldier
We must now turn your sternness into courtship
When ye have done there; to your fair repose sir:Flourish.
I know you need it Memnon, welcome gentlemen. Ex. ki.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.l: Now he begins to march: madam the van's yours,
Keep your ground sure; 'tis for your spurs.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: O Venus. He kneels amazed and forgets to speak.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How he stares on me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Knight him madam, knight him
He will grow tooth 'Ground else.

sp.speaker: Eumenes.
sp.l: Speak sir, 'tis the Princess.

sp.speaker: 1 captain
sp.l: Ye shame yourself, speak to her

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Rise and speak sir.
Ye are welcome to the court, to me, to all sir,

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Is he not deaf?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The gentleman's not well.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Fie noble general,

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Give him fresh air his colour goes, how do ye?
The Princess will be glad sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Peace, and hear me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Command a silence there.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I love thee lady.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I thank your lordship heartily: proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Lord how it stuck in's stomach like a surfeit.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: It breaks apace now from him, God be thanked,
What a fine spoken man he is.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A choice one of singular variety in carriage.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes and I warrant you he knows his distance.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: With all my heart I love thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A hearty gentleman,
And I were e'en an errand beast, my lord,
But I loved you again.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Good lady kiss me.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: I marry, Mars, there thou cam'st close up to her.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Kiss you at first my lord, 'tis no fair fashion,
Our lips are like rose buds, blown with men's breathes,
They lose both sap and savour; there's my hand sir.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Fie, fie, my lord, this is too rude.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Unhand me,
Consume me if I hurt her; good sweet lady
Let me but look upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well sir.
Take your full view.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Bless your eyes sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Mercy,
Is this the man they talked of for a soldier,
So absolute and excellent: oh the gods,
If I were given to that vanity
Of making sport with men for ignorance,
What a most precious subject had I purchased?
Speak for him gentlemen: some one that knows,
What the man ails; and can speak sense.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sure madam,
This fellow has been a rare hare finder
See how his eyes are set.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Some one go with me,
I'll send him something, for his head, poor gentleman,
Is troubled with the staggers.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Keep him dark,
He will run march mad else, the fumes of battles
Ascend into his brains,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Clap to his feet
An old drum head, to draw the thunder downward.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Look to him gentlemen: farewell, lord I am sorry
We cannot kiss at this time, but believe it
We'll find an hour for all: God keep my children,
From being such sweet soldiers; softly wenches,
Lest we disturb his dream. Exit Calis and ladies.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Why this is monstrous.

sp.speaker: 1 captain
sp.l: A strange forgetfulness, yet still he holds it.

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.l: Though he never saw a woman of great fashion
Before this day, yet my thinks 'tis possible
He might imagine what they are, and what
Belongs unto 'em; mere report of others.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Pish, his head had other whimsies in't: my lord,
Death I think you're struck dumb; my good lord general

sp.speaker: 1 captain
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: That I do love ye madam; and so love ye
An't like your grace.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: He has been studying this speech.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Who do ye speak to sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why where's the lady
The woman, the fair woman.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The Princess,
Give me the Princess.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Give ye counsel rather
To use her like a Princess: fie my lord,
How have you born yourself, how nakedly
Laid your soul open: and your ignorance
To be a sport to all; report and honour;
Drew her to do you favours, and you bluntly,
Without consideration what, or how she was
Neither collecting reason, nor distinction.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, what did I my masters?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: All that shows
A man unhandsome, undigested done.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Did not I kneel unto her?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Dumb and senseless,
As though ye had been cut out for your father's tomb,
Or stuck a landmark; when she spoke unto you,
Being the excellence of all our island,
Ye stared upon her, as ye had seen a monster

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Was I so foolish; I confess Eumenes,
I never saw before so brave an outside
But did I kneel so long

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Till they laughed at ye,
And when you spoke, I am ashamed to tell ye
What 'twas my lord; how far from order;
Bless me, is't possible the wild noise of a war
And what she only teaches should possess ye,
Knowledge to treat with her, and full discretion
Being at flood still in ye, and in peace,
And manly conversation smooth and civil,
Where gracefulness and glory twin together
Thrust yourself out an exile?
Do you know sir, what state she carries?
What great obedience waits at her back continually?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: She never commanded
A hundred thousand men, as I have done,
Nor never won battle; say I would have kissed her.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: There was a dainty offer too, a rare one.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, she is a woman, is she not?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: She is so.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why, very well; what was she made for then?
Is she not young and handsome bred to breed?
Do not men kiss fair women? if they do,
If lips be not unlawful ware; why a Princess
Is got the same way that we get a beggar,
Or I am cozened; and the selfsame way
She must be handled e'er she get another,
That's rudeness is it not?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: To her 'tis held so, and rudeness in that high degree.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Tis reason,
But I will be more punctual; pray what thought she?

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Her thoughts were merciful, but she laughed at ye,
Pitying the poorness of your compliment,
And so she left ye, good sir shape yourself
To understand the place, and noble persons
You live with now.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Let not those great deserts
The King hath laid up of ye, and the people,
Be blasted with ill bearing.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: The whole name of soldier, then will suffer,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: She's a sweet one.
And good sirs leave your exhortations
They come untimely to me, I have brains
That beat above your reaches: she's a Princess,
That's all: I have killed a King, that's greater.
Come let's to dinner, if the wine be good,
You shall perceive strange wisdom in my blood.

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Well, would thou wert i'the wars again
Old Memnon, there thou wouldst talk toth' purpose,
And the proudest of all these court chameleons
Would be glad to find it sense too: plague of this
Dead peace, this bastard breeding lousy lazy idleness,
Now we must learn to pipe, and pick our livings
Out of old rotten ends: these twenty five years
I have served my country, lost my youth and blood,
Exposed my life to dangers more than days.
Yet let me tell my wants, I know their answers,
The King is bound to right me, they good people
Have but from hand to mouth, look to your wives
Your young trim wives, your high-day wives, your marchpanes,
For if the soldiers find not recompense,
As yet there's none a hatching; I believe
You men of wars, the men of wars will nick ye,
For starve nor beg they must not, my small means
Are gone in fumo: here to raise a better
Unless it be with lying, or dog flattering,
At which our nations excellent; observing dog-days,
When this good lady broils, and would be basted
By that good lord or such like moral learning's,
Is here impossible; well, I will rub among 'em
If any thing for honesty be gotten,
Thou'lt be but bread and cheese I can be satisfied,
If otherwise the wind blow, stiff as I am
Yet I shall learn to shuffle: there's an old lass
That shall be nameless yet alive, my last hope,
Has often got me my pocket full of crowns
If all fail, jackdaws, are you alive still?
Then I see the coast clear, when fools and boys can prosper.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Brave lieutenant

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Haile to the man of worship.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You are fine sirs,
Most passing fine at all points.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: As ye see sir,
Homebred and handsome, we cut not out our clothes sir
At half sword as your tailors do, and pink 'em
With pikes and partisans, we live retired sir
Gentlemen like, and jealous of our honours.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Very fine fool, and fine boy, peace plays with you
As the wind plays with feathers, dances ye
You grind with all gusts gallants.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: We can bounce sir,
When you soldados bend i'th' hams, and frisk too.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: When twenty of your trip-coats turn their tippets,
And your cold salads without salt or vinegar
By wambling in your stomachs, hemp and hobnails
Will bear no price now, hanging and old harness
Are like to overrun us.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Whores and hot houses.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Surgeons and syringes ring out your sance-bells.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Your jubilee, your jubilee.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Proh deum.
How our st. George's will bestride the dragons
The red and ramping dragons.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Advanced fool.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: But then the sting i'th' tail boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Tanto melior.
For so much the more danger, the more honour.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You're very pleasant with our occupation gent.
Which very like amongst these fiery serpents
May light upon a blind-worm of your blood,
A mother or a sister.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Mine's past saddle
You should be sure of her else: but say sir Huon
Now the drums dubs, and the sticks turned bed-staves,
All the old foxes hunted to their holes,
The iron age returned to eribus,
And honorificabilitudinitatibus
Thrust out o'th' kingdom by the head and shoulders,
What trade do you mean to follow.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's a question.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Yes and a learned question if ye mark it,
Consider and say on.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Fooling as thou dost, that's the best trade I take it.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Take it straight then
For fear your fellows be before ye, hark ye lieutenant
Foolings the thing, the thing worth all your fightings,
When all's done ye must fool sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Well, I must then.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: But do you know what fooling is; true fooling
The circumstances that belong unto it,
For every idle knave that shows his teeth
Wants and would live can juggle tumble, fiddle,
Make a dog face, or can abuse his fellow,
Is not a fool at first dash, you shall find sir
Strange turnings in this trade; to fool is nothing
As fooling has been but to fool the fair way,
The new way, as the best men fool their friends,
For all men get by fooling merely fooling,
Desert does nothing valiant, wise, virtuous,
Are things that walk by without bread or breeches,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I partly credit that.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Fine wits, fine wits sir,
There's the young boy, he does well in his way too,
He could not live else in his master's absence;
He ties a lady's garters so, so, prettily,
Say his hand slip, but say so.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why let it slip then.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one the body shall come after,
And he that works deserves his wages.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's true.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: He riddles finely to a waiting gentlewoman
Expounds dreams like a prophet, dreams himself too,
And wishes all dreams true; they cry amen,
And there's a memorandum: he can sing too
Bawdy enough to please old ladies: he lies rarely,
Pawns ye a suit of clothes at all points, fully,
Can pick a pocket if ye please, or casket;
Lisps when he lists to catch a chambermaid,
And calls his hostess mother, these are things now,
If a man mean to live, to fight and swagger,
Beaten about the ears with bawling sheepskins,
Cut to the soul for summer: here an arm lost,
And there a leg; his honourable head
Sealed up in salves and searcloths, like a packet,
And so sent over to an hospital, stand there, charge there,
Swear there, whore there, dead there,
And all this sport for cheese, and chines of dog-flesh,
And money when two wednesdays meet together,
Where to be lousy is a gentleman,
And he that wears a clean shirt has his
Shroud on.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I'll be your scholar, come if I like fooling.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: You cannot choose but like it, fight you one day
I'll fool another, when your surgeons paid,
And all your leaks stopped, see whose slops are heaviest,
I'll have a shilling for a can of wine,
When you shall have two sergeants for a counter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come learn of us lieutenant, hang your iron up,
We'll find you cooler wars.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come let's together,
I'll see your tricks, and as I like 'em. —Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why was there not such women in the camp then
Prepared to make me know 'em.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: 'Twas no place sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Captain
sp.l: Why should they live in tumults: they are creatures
Soft and of sober natures.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Could not your wives,
Your mothers, or your sisters have been sent for
To exercise upon.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: We thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: But do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I do mean.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To see her,
And see thee hanged too, and thou anger'st me,
And thousands of your throats cut, get ye from me
Ye keep a prating of your points of manners,
And fill my head with lousy circumstances,
Better have ballets in 't your courtly worships,
How to put off my hat, you how to turn me,
And you forsooth to blow my nose discreetly;
Let me alone, for I will love her, see her,
Talk to her, and mine own way.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: She's the Princess.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why let her be the devil, I have spoke,
When thunder durst not check me, I must love,
I know she was a thing kept for me.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: And I know sir,
Though she were born yours, yet your strange behaviour
And want.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: I do not.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: I do not lie sir,
I say you want fair language, nay 'tis certain
You cannot say good morrow.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye dog-whelps,
The proudest of your prating tongues.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Do kill us,
Kill us for telling truth, for my part general
I would not live to see men make a may-game
Of him I have made a master, kill us quickly,
Than ye may.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Do what you list, draw your sword childishly
Upon your servants that are bound to tell ye
I am weary of my life.

sp.speaker: 1 captain
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.l: And all sir.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Go to the Princess make her sport, cry to her
I am the glorious man of war.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Pray ye leave me,
I am sorry I was angry, I'll think better,
Pray no more words.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.p: We are gone sir. Exeunt Eume. and captains.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: How came he hither, see for heaven's sake wenches,
What faces, and what postures he puts on,Mem. walks aside full of strange gestures.
I do not think he is perfect.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If your love
Have not betrayed his little wits, he's well enough.
As well as he will be.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Mark how he muses.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Has a battalia now in's brains, he draws out now
Have at ye harpers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: See, see, there the fire fails.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Look what an alphabet of faces he runs through,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O love, love, how amorously thou lookest
In an old rusty armour.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'll away, for by my troth I fear him.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Fear the god's madam,
And never care what man can do, this fellow
Withal his frights about him and his furies,
His larums and his lances, swords and targets,
Nay case him up in armour cap-a-pe,
Yet durst I undertake within two hours,
If he durst charge to give him such a shake
Should shake his valour off, and make his shanks too

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: For shame no more.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: He muses still.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The devil.
Why should this old dried timber chopped with thunder.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Old wood burns quickest.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Out you would say madam,
Give me a green stick that may hold me heat
And smoke me soundly too: 'a turns, and sees ye.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: There's no avoiding now, have at ye. Memnon comes to her.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Lady,
The more I look upon ye. Stays her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The more you may sir.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let him alone.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I would desire your patience
The more I say I look, the moreStays her.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: My fortune
'Tis very apt sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Women let my fortune
And me alone I wish ye, pray come this way
And stand you still there lady

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Leave the words sir, and leap into the meaning

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then again.
I tell you I do love ye

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No questions: pray no more questions.
I do love you. Infinitely, why do you smile.
Am I ridiculous

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am monstrous fearful, no I joy you love me

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Joy on then and be proud on't, I do love ye,
Stand still do not trouble me you women.
He loves you lady at whose feet has kneeled
Princes to beg their freedoms, he whose valour
Has over run whole kingdoms

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: That makes me doubt sir
'Twill over run me to

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: He whose sword

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Talk not so big sir, you will fright the Princess.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha. Lucip. No forsooth

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I know ye have done wonders.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I have and will do more and greater braver.
And for your beauty miracles, name that kingdom
And talk your choice:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sir I am not ambitious

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye shall be, 'tis the child of glory: she that I love
Whom my desires shall magnify time storeys
And all the empire of the earth:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I would fain ask him.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Prithee be quiet, he will beat us both else.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What will ye make me then sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will make thee
Stand still and hold thy peace, I have a heart lady

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ye were a monster else

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A loving heart
A truly loving heart:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas how came it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I would you had it in your hand sweet lady
To see the truth it bears ye:

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Do you give it.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: That was well thought upon:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Twill put him to't wench;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And you shall see I dare accept it sir
Take't in my hand and view it: if I find it
A loving and a sweet heart as you call it
I am bound, I am

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No more I'll send it to ye
As I have honour in me you shall have it

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Handsomely done sir, and perfumed by all means
The weathers warm sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: With all circumstance

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A napkin wrought most curiously;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Divinely

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Put in a goblet of pure gold

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes in jacynth
That she may see the spirits through

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Ye have greased him
For chewing love again in haste

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If he should do it

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If heaven should fall we should have larks, he do

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: See how he thinks upon't

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He will think these three years
Ere he prove such an ass, I liked his offer
There was no other way to put him of else.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will do it
Lady expect my heart

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I do sir:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Love it and so I leave ye. Ex. Mem.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Either he is stark mad
Or else I think he means it

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He must be stark mad
Or he will never do it, 'tis vain glory
And want of judgement that provokes this in him
Sleep and society cures all his heart
No no good gentleman there's more belongs to't
Hearts are at higher prizes, let's go in
And there examine him a little better.
Shut all the doors behind for fear he follow
I hope I have lost a lover, and am glad on't. Exit. Lady.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Tis but to die, dogs do it, ducks with dabbling,
Birds sing away their souls, and babies sleep 'em,
Why do I talk of that is treble vantage,
For in the other world she is bound to have me,
Her princely word is past: my great desert too
Will draw her to come after presently
'Tis justice, and the gods must see it done too
Besides no brother, father, kindred there
Can hinder us, all languages are a like too
There love is everlasting, ever young
Free from diseases, ages, jealousies.
Bawds, beldames, painters, purgers, die, 'tis nothing
Men drown themselves for joy to draw in juleps
When they are hot with wine, in dreams we do it,
And many a handsome wench that loves the sport well
Gives up her soul so in her lover's bosom,
But I must be incised first, cut and opened
My heart and handsomely ta'ne from me, stay there
Dead once stay, let me think again, who do I know there
For else to wander up and down unwait on
And unregarded in my place and project
Is for a sowter's soul, not an old soldiers.
My brave old regiments: I there it goes
That have been killed before me, right,

sp.speaker: Chil.
sp.l: Is here, and I must trouble him.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then those I have conquered
To make my train full:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My captains then:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Sir I beseech ye

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For to meet her there
Being a Princess and a King's sole sister
With great accommodation must be cared for

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Weigh but the soldier's poverty

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Mine own troop first
For they shall die:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: How what's this

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Next:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall I speak louder sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A square battalions:

sp.speaker: Hi
sp.l: You do not think of us.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Their armours guilded:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Good noble sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And round about such engines
Shall make hell shake:

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye do not mock me

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For sir
I will be strange as brave

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye may consider
You know we have served you long enough

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No soldier
That ever landed on the blessed Elysium
Did or shall march, as I will

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Would ye would march sir
Up to the King and get us

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: King nor keiser
Shall equal me in that world

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What a devil ails he

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Next the rare beauties of those towns I fired

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I speak of money sir:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ten thousand coaches

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O pounds sir, pounds I beseech your lordship
Let coaches run out of your remembrance

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In which the wanton Cupids; and the graces
Drawn with the western winds kindling desires,
And then our poets.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then our pay

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For Chilax when the triumph comes; the Princess
Then for I will have a heaven made

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Bless your lordship I
Stand still sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So I do and in it

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Death sir
You talk you know not what

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Such rare devices:
Make me I say a heaven

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I say so too sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For here shall run a constellation

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And there a pissing conduit

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: With wine sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: A sun there in his height, there such a planet

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But where's our money where runs that

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Money
Money an't like your lordship

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why all the carriage, shall come behind the stuff
Rich hangings, treasure
Or say we have none

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I may say so truly
For hang me if I have a groat: I have served well
And like an honest man: I see no reason

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou must needs die good Chilax

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Very well sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will have honest, valiant souls about me
I cannot miss thee

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Die?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes die, and Pelius
Eumenes and Polybius: I shall think
Of more within these two hours

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Die sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I sir
And ye shall die

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When I beseech your lordship

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Tomorrow see ye do die

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A short warning,
Troth sir I am ill prepared

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I die myself then
Beside there's reason

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I pray thee tell me
For thou art a great dreamer

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I can dream sir
If I eat well and sleep well

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Was it never
By dream or apparition opened to thee?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: He's mad

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What the other world was, or Elysium?
Didst never travel in thy sleep?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: To taverns
When I was drunk o'er night: or to a wench
There's an Elysium for ye, a young lady
Wrapped round about ye like a snake: is that it?
Or if that strange Elysium that you talk of
Be where the devil is, I have dreamt of him
And that I have had him by the horns, and rid him
He trots the dagger out oth' sheath

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Elysium,
The blessed fields, man

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I know no fields blessed, but those I have gained by
I have dreamed I have been in heaven too

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There, handle that place; that's Elysium

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Brave singing, and brave dancing
And rare things

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: All full of flowers

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And pot herbs

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Bowers for lovers
And everlasting ages of delight

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I slept not so far

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Meet me on those banks
Some two days hence

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: In dream sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No in death sir
And there I muster all, and pay the soldier
Away, no more, no more

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: God keep your lordship
This is fine dancing for us

sp.speaker: Syphax.
sp.l: Where's the general

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: There's the old sign of Memnon, where the soul is
You may go look as I have

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What's the matter

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why question him and see; he talks of devils
Hells, heavens, princes, powers, and potentates,
You must to'th pot too

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.p: Do you know Elysium a tale he talks the wild goose chase of

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Elysium? I have red of such a place.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then get he to him
Ye are as fine company as can be fitted. Exit Chilax.
Your worships fairly met

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Mercy upon us,
What ails this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Provision

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How his head works.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Between two ribs
If he cut short or mangle me; I'll take him
And twirl his neck about

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Now gods defend us

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In a pure cup transparent with a writing
To signify

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I never knew him thus
Sure is bewitched, or poisoned;

sp.speaker: Mem,
sp.l: Who's there

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither Syphax

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes; how does your lordship

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Well God a mercy soldier, very well
But prithee tell me

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Any thing I can sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: What durst thou do to gain the rarest beauty
The world has

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: That the world has? 'tis worth doing

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Is it so? but what doing bears it?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why any thing, all dangers it appears to

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Name some of those things; do

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I would undertake sir
A voyage round about the world

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short Syphax,
A merchant does it to spice pots of ale

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I wooed swim in armour

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short still: a poor jade
Laden will take a stream and stem it strongly
To leap a mare

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: The plague I durst

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Still shorter
I'll cure it with an onion

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Surfeits

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Short still
They are often physics for our healths and help us.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I wooed stand a breach

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thine honour bids thee soldier
'Tis shame to find a second cause

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I durst sir
Fight with the fellest monster

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: That's the poorest,
Man was ordained their master; durst ye die sir?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: How? die my lord!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Die Syphax: take thy sword
And come by that door to her; there's a prize
To buy a lusty love at

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I am well content sir
To prove no purchaser

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Away thou world worm,
Thou win a matchless beauty?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Tis to loos't sir
For being dead where's the reward I reach at,
The love I labour for?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There it begins fool
Thou art merely cozened; for the loves we now know
Are but the heats of half an hour; and hated
Desires stirred up by nature to increase her
Licking of one another to a lust;
Course and base appetites earth's mere inheritors
And heirs of idleness and blood; pure love
That that the soul affects and cannot purchase
While she is laden with our flesh, that love sir
Which is the price of honour dwells not here,
Your lady's eyes are lampless to that virtue,
That beauty smiles not on a cheek washed over,
Nor scents the sweets of ambers; below, Syphax
Below us, in the other word, Elysium,
Where's no more dying, no despairing, mourning,
Where all desires are full, deserts down laden,
There Syphax, there, where loves are ever living,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why do we love in this world then?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: To preserve it,
The maker lost his work else: but mark Syphax,
What issues that love bears.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why children sir;
I never heard him talk thus; thus divinely
And sensible before

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: It does so, Syphax,
Things like ourselves, as sensual vain unvented
Bubbles and breath of airs, got with an itching
As blisters are; and bred, as much corruption
Flows from their lives, sorrow conceives and shapes 'em
And oftentimes the deaths of those we love most
The breeders bring them to the world to curse 'em,
Crying they weep amongst us like young cats,
Cares and continual crosses keeping with 'em,
They make time old to tend them and experience
An ass they alter so; they grow and goodly
'Ere we can turn our thoughts, like drops of water
They fall into the main, and known no more;
This is the love of this world: I must tell thee
For thou art understanding

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What you please sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And as a faithful man
Nay I dare trust thee
I love the Princess

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: There 'tis that has fired him
I knew he had some inspiration
But does she know it sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes marry does she
I have given my heart unto her

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: If ye love her

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Nay understand me, my heart taken from me
Out of my body man and so brought to her
How likest thou that brave offer? there's the love
I told thee of; and after death the living;
She must in justice, come boy, ha?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Your heart sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ay, so by all means Syphax

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: He loves roast well
That eats the spit

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And since thou art come thus fitly
I'll do it presently and thou shall carry it
For thou canst tell a story and describe it
And I conjure thee Syphax by thy gentry
Next by the glorious battles we have fought in
By all the dangers, wounds, heats, colds, distresses,
Thy love next and obedience, nay thy life

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: But one thing first sir, if she pleased to grant it
Could ye not love her here and live, consider

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha? yes I think I could

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Twould be far nearer
Besides the sweets here, would induce the last love
And link it in

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou sayest right, but our ranks here
And bloods are bars between us, she must stand off too
As I perceive she does

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Desert and duty
Makes even all sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then the King, though I
Have merited as much as man can; must not let her,
So many princes covetous of beauty;
I wooed with all my heart but 'tis impossible

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Why say she marry after

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No she dare not
The gods dare not do ill: come

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Do you mean it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Lend me thy knife, and help me of

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: For heaven's sake
Be not so stupid mad dear general.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Dispatch, I say.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: As ye love that ye look for
Heaven and the blessed life.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Hell take thee coxcomb,
Why dost thou keep me from it; thy knife, I say.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Do but this one thing, on my knees I beg it,
Stay but two hours till I return again,
For I will to her, tell her all your merits,
Your most valued love, and last your danger;
If she relent, then live still, and live loving,
Happy, and high in favour: if she frown;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Shall I be sure to know it.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: As I live sir,
My quick return shall either bring ye fortune,
Or leave you to your own fate.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Two hours?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Let it be kept, away, I will expect it. Exeunt Memnon Syphax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: You dainty wits two, an ye to a cater,
To cheat him of a dinner.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ten at court sir
Are few enough, they are as wise as we are.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hang ye, I'll eat at any time: and anywhere
I never make that part of want, preach to me
What ye can do, and when ye list.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Your patience,
'Tis a hard day at court, a fish day.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: So it seems sir,
The fins grow out of thy face.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And to purchase
This day the company of one dear custard,
Or a mess of rice ap Thomas, needs a main wit;
Beef we can bear before us lined with brews
And tubs of pork; vociferating veals,
And tongues that never told lie yet.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Line thy mouth with 'em

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Thou hast need, and great need,
For these finny fish-days,
The officers understandings are so phlegmatic,
They cannot apprehend us.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: That's great pity,
For you deserve it, and being apprehended
The whip to boot; boy what do you so near me,
I dare not trust your touch boy.

div.stage: Enter Stremon and his boy Ed. Hor.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: As I am virtuous
What, thieves among ourselves?

sp.speaker: Chy.
sp.l: Stremon.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Welcome ashore, ashore.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: What Monsieur, music?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: My fine fool.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Fellow crack, why what a consort
Are we now blessed withal?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Fooling and fiddling
Nay and we live not now boys; what new songs sirrah.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: A thousand man, a thousand.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Itching airs
Alluding to the old sport.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Of all sizes.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And how does small Tim treble here; the heart on't.

sp.speaker: Boy. 2.
sp.l: To do you service.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: O Tim the times, the times Tim.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: How does the general,
And next what moneys stirring?

sp.speaker: Chy.
sp.l: For the general
Is here, but such a general
The times changed Stremon,
He was the liberal general, and the loving,
The feeder of a soldier, and the father,
But now become the stupidest.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Why, what ails he.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nay, if a horse knew, and his head's big enough
I'll hang for't; didst thou ever see a dog
Run mad o'th' toothache, such another toy
Is he now so, 'a gloats and grins, and bites.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Why hang him quickly,
And then he cannot hurt folks.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: One hour raving,
Another smiling, not a word the third hour,
I tell thee Stremon has a stirring soul,
Whatever it attempts or labours at
Would wear out twenty bodies in another.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: I'll keep it out of me, for mine's but buckram,
He would bounce that out in two hours.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then he talks
The strangest and the maddest stuff from reason,
Or any thing ye offer; stand thou there,
I'll show thee how he is, for I'll play Memnon
The strangest general that ere thou heardst of Stremon.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Go presently and find me
A black horse with a blue tail; bid the blank cornet
Charge through the sea, and sink the navy: softly,
Our souls are things not to be wakened in us
With larums, and loud bawlings, for in Elysium
Stillness and quietness, and sweetness, sirrah,
I will have, for it much concerns mine honour,
Such a strong reputation for my welcome
As all the world shall say: for in the forefront
So many on white unicorns, next them
My gentlemen, my cavaliers and captains,
Ten deep and trapped with tenterhooks to take hold
Of all occasions: for Friday cannot fish out
The end I aim at; tell me of Diocles,
And what he dare do, dare he meet me naked
Thunder in this hand, in his left? Fool?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Fool, I would have thee fly i'th' air fly swiftly
To that place where the sun sets, there deliver.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Deliver? what sir?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: This sir, this ye slave sir,All laugh.
Death ye rude rogues, ye scarabs.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Hold for heavens sake lieutenant, sweet lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I have done sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You have wrung his neck off.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No boy, 'tis the nature
Of this strange passion when't hits to hale people
Along by th'hair, to kick 'em, break their heads:

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Do ye call this acting, was your part to beat me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Yes, I must act all that he does.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Plague act ye,
I'll act no more.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: 'Tis but to show man.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Then man
He should have showed it only, and not done it,
I am sure he beat me beyond action,
Gouts a your heavy fist.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I'll have thee to him,
Thou hast a fine wit, fine fool, and canst play rarely.
He'll hug thee, boy, and stroke thee,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I'll to the stocks first,
'Ere I be stroked thus.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: But how came he Chilax?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I know not that,

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: I'll to him

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: He loves thee well,
And much delights to hear thee sing; much taken
He has been with thy battle songs.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: If music,
Can find his madness; I'll so fiddle a him,
That out it shall by'th shoulders,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: My fine fiddler,
He'll firk you and ye take not heed too: 'twill be rare sport
To see his own trade triumph over him;
His lute laced to his head, for creeping hedges;
For money there's none stirring; try good Stremon
Now what your silver sound can do; our voices
Are but vain echoes,

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Something shall be done
Shall make him understand all; let's to'th tavern,
I have some few crowns left yet: my whistle wet once
I'll pipe him such a pavane -

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hold thy head up,
Je cure it with a quart of wine; come coxcomb;
Come boy take heed of napkins.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: You'd no more acting?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more chicken;

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Go then.

div.stage: Enter Syphax at one door, and a gentleman at another.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: God save you sir; pray how might I see the Princess

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why very fitly sir she's even now ready,
To wake out this way into'th park; stand there,
Ye cannot miss her sight, sir,

sp.speaker: Syphax.
sp.l: I much thank ye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Let's have a care, for I'll assure ye wenches
I would not meet him willingly again;
For though I do not fear him, yet his fashion
I wood not be acquainted much with.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Gentle lady,
Ye need not fear the walks are viewed and empty,
But my thinks madam this kind heart of his —

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Is slow a coming.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Keep me ye blessed angels,
What killing power is this?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why dost thou look for't?
Dost think he spoke in earnest?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: My thinks madam,
A gentleman should keep his word; and to a lady
A lady of your excellencies;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Out fool!
Send me his heart? what should we do wilt? dance it?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Dry it and drink it for the worms.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Who's that?
What man stands there?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A gentleman,
Which I beseech your grace to honour so much,
As know him for your servant's brother.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Syphax?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: The same an't please your grace; what does he here?
Upon what business and I ignorant?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He's grown a handsome gentleman; good Syphax
Yet welcome from the wars; would ye with us sir?
Pray speak your will: a blushes, be not fearful ,
I can assure ye for your sister's sake sir,
There's my hand on it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sure these soldiers,
Are all grown senseless,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Do ye know where ye are sir?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Tongue-tied,
He looks not well too, by my life, I think;

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Speak, for shame speak.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: A man would speak —

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: These soldiers,
Are all dumb saints: consider and take time sir,
Let's forward wenches come, his palates down.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Dare these men charge it'h face of fire and bullets?
And hang there heads down at a handsome woman?
Good master Mars that is a soul fault.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fie beast,
No more my brother.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Sister, honoured sister,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Dishonoured fool,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: I do confess,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Fie on thee,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: But stay till I deliver,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Let me go,
I am a shame to own thee,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Fare ye well then,
Ye must ne'er see me more,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Why stay dear Syphax,
My anger's past; I will hear ye speak

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O sister,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Out with it man,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O I have drunk my mischief,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ha? what?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: My destruction.
In at mine eyes I have drunk it; oh the Princess,
The rare sweet Princess!

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: How fool? the rare Princess?
Was it the Princess that thou saidst?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: The Princess,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Thou dost not love her sure, thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Yes by heaven,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Yes by heaven? I know thou dar'st not,
The Princess? 'tis thy life the knowledge of it,
Presumption that will draw into it all thy kindred,
And leave 'em slaves and succourless; the Princess?
Why she's a sacred thing to see and worship,
Fixed from us as the sun is high and glorious,
To be adored not doted on; desire things possible,
Thou foolish young man, nourish not a hope,
Will hail thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: 'Tis my destiny,
And I know both disgrace and death will quit it,
If it be known

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Pursue it not then Syphax
Get thee good wholesome thoughts may nourish thee.
Go home and pray

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I cannot

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Sleep then Syphax.
And dream away thy doting.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I must have her
Or you no more your brother; work Cleanthe ,
Work, and work speedily, or I shall die wench.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Die then, I dare forget; farewell

sp.speaker: Syp.
sp.l: Farewell sister.
Farewell for ever, see me buried.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Stay.
Pray stay? he's all my brothers: no way Syphax.
No other woman,

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: None, none, she or sinking.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Go and hope well, my life I'll venture for thee
And all my art, a woman may work miracles;
No more, pray heartily against my fortunes,
For much I fear a main one.

sp.speaker: Syphax.
sp.l: I shall do it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter a priest of Venus and a boy.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Find him by any means; and good child tell him
He has forgotten his old friend, give him this,
And say this night without excuse or business
As ever he may find a friend, come to me,
He knows the way and how, begone.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I gallop. Exit boy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: I have been looking you;

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: The fair Cleanthe,
What may your business be?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O holy mother
Such business of such strange wait, now or never.
As ye have loved me, as ye do or may do,
When I shall find a fit time.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: If by my means
Your business may be fitted; ye know me,
And how I am tied unto you; be bold daughter
To build your best hopes,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: O but 'tis a strange one
Stuck with as many dangers -

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: There's the working,
Small things perform themselves and give no pleasures;
Be confident through death I'll serve.

sp.speaker: Clean
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Fie no corruption

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Take it; 'tis yours,
Be not so spiced, 'tis good gold
And goodness is no gall to'th conscience,
I know you have ways to vent it: ye may hold it

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: I'll keep it for ye; when?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning
I'll visit ye again; and when occasion
Offers itself -

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Instruct me, and have at ye -

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Farewell till then; be sure.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: As your own thoughts, lady.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'Tis a main work and full of fear.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Fool's onlyExit Cle.
Make their effects seem fearful: farewell daughter.
This gold was well got for my old tough soldier
Now I shall be his sweet again; what business
Is this she has a foot? some lusty lover
Beyond her line, the young wench would fain piddle
A little to revive her, must be thought of,
'Tis even so; she must have it; but how by my means
A devil can she drive it? I that wait still
Before the goddess giving oracle
How can I profit her? 'tis her own project,
And if she cast it false her own fault be it. Exit. Priest.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Why this is utter madness

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Thus it is sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Only the Princess sight?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: All we can judge at;

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: This must be looked to timely.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yes and wisely;

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He does not offer at his life

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Not yet sir
That we can hear of

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Noble gentlemen;
Let me entreat your watches over him.
Ye cannot do a worthier work.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: We came sir
Provided for that service?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Where is Chilax?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: A little busy sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is the fool and boy here.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: They are sir,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Let 'em be still so; and as they find his humors

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Now ye may behold him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Stand close and work no noise;
By his eyes now, gentlemen,
I guess him full of anger

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Be not seen there

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The hour's passed long ago, he's false and fearful,
Coward go with thy catine soul, thou our dog.
Thou cold clod, wild fire warm thee, monstrous fearful,
I know the slave shakes but to think on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: But I shall catch ye rascal,
Your mangy soul is not immortal here sir,
Ye must die, and we must meet; we must, maggot,
Be sure we must, for not a nook of hell,
Not the most horrid pit shall harbour thee.
The devil's tail shall hide thee, but I'll have thee,
And how I'll use thee, whips and firebrands
Toasting thy tail against a flame of wild fire,
And basting it with brimstone, shall be nothing,
Nothing at all; I'll reach ye to be treacherous;
Was never slave so swinged since hell was hell
As I will swinge thy slave's soul: and be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is this imagination, or some circumstance
For 'tis extreme strange.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: So is all he does sir

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Till then I'll leave ye? who's there? where's the surgeon.
Demagoras. Enter surgeon.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: My lord,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Bring the surgeon.
And wait you too. Enter surgeon.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: What wood ye with a surgeon

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Things mustering in his head: pray mark

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither.
Have you brought your instruments.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: They are within sir,

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Put to the doors a while there; ye can incise
To a hair's breadth without defacing;

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And take out fairly from the flesh;

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: The least thing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Well, come hither then; take off my doublet,
For look ye surgeon, I must have ye cut
My heart out here, and handsomely: nay, stare not,
Nor do not start; I'll cut your throat else surgeon,
Come swear to do it.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Good sir —

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sirrah, hold him,
I'll have but one blow at his head.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I'll do it,
Why what should we do living after you sir?
We'll die before if ye please.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Living? hang living,
Is there never a cat hole where I may creep through?
Wooed I were in the Indies.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Swear then, and after my death presently
To kill yourselves and follow, as ye are honest,
As ye have faiths and loves to me.

sp.speaker: Dema.
sp.l: We'll do it.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Pray do not stir yet, we are near enough
To run between all dangers.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Here I am sir;
Come look upon me, view the best way boldly,
Fear nothing but cut home; if your hand shake sirrah,
Or any way deface my heart i'th' cutting,
Make the least scratch upon it, but draw it whole,
Excellent fair, showing at all points, surgeon,
The honour and the valour of the owner,
Mixed with the most immaculate love I send it,
Look to't, I'll slice thee to the soul.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Never fear sir,
I'll do it daintily; would I were out once.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will not have ye smile sirrah when ye do it,
As though ye cut a lady's corn; 'tis scurvy;
Do me it as thou dost thy prayers, seriously.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I'll do it in a dump sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In a dog sir,
I'll have no dumps, nor dumplings: fetch your tools,
And then I'll tell ye more.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: If I return
To hear more I'll be hanged for't.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Dema.
sp.l: Yes sir,
With all the heels we have,Exeunt surgeon. Demagoras.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yet stand.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: He'll do it.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He cannot and we here.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why when ye rascals,
Ye dull slaves: will ye come sir? Surgeon, serring,
Dogleach, shall I come fetch ye?

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Now I'll to him,
God save ye honoured brother

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My dear Polidor,
Welcome from travel welcome; and how do ye?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well sir, would you were so.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I am, I thank ye,
You are a bettered man much, I the same still,
An old rude soldier, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Pray be plain brother,
And tell me but the meaning of this vision,
For to me it appears no more: so far
From common course and reason.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thank thee fortune,
At length I have found the man: the man must do it,
The man in honour bound.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: To do what?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Hark, for I will bless ye with the circumstance
Of that weak shadow that appeared.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Speak on sir. Walks with him.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: It is no story for all ears.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The Princess?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Peace and hear all: how:

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sure 'tis dangerous
He starts so at it,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Your heart, do ye know sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yes, pray thee be softer.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Me to do it?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Only reserved, and dedicated.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: For shame brother
Know, what, ye are, a man.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: None of your Athens
Good sweet sir, no philosophy, thou feelest not
The honourable end, fool.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I am sure I feel
The shame and scorn that follows; have ye served thus long
The glory of your country, in your conquests,
The envy of your neighbours, in your virtues,
Ruled armies of your own, given laws to nations,
Beloved and feared as far as fame has travelled,
Called the most fortunate and happy Memnon,
To lose all here at home, poorly to lose it,
Poorly and pettishly, ridiculously
To fling away your fortune? where's your wisdom?
Where's that you governed others by, discretion?
Does your rule lastly hold upon yourself? fie brother,
How are ye fallen? get up into your honour
The top branch of your bravery, and from thence
Look and lament how little Memnon seems now.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Hum! 'tis well spoken; but dost thou think, young scholar
The tongues of angels from my happiness
Could turn the end I aim at? no: they cannot;
This is no book case brother: will ye do it?
Use no more art, I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ye may, sir
Command me to do any thing that's honest,
And for your noble end: but this it carries.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ye shall not be so honoured; live an ass still,
And learn to spell for profit: go, go study.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ye must not hold him up so, he is lost then.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Get thee to school again, and talk of turnips,
And find the natural cause out, why a dog
Turns thrice about e'er he lie down: there's learning.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come, I will do it now; 'tis brave, I find it,
And now allow the reason.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: O do ye so sir,
Do ye find it currant?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, yes, excellent.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I told ye.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I was foolish: I have here too
The rarest way to find the truth out; hark ye,
Ye shall be ruled by me.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will be: but —

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I reach it,
If the worst fall, have at the worst: we'll both go
But two days, and 'tis thus; ha?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: 'Twill do well so

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then if not excellent, do ye conceive it

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: 'Twill work for certainA bowl ready.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O 'twill tickle her
And you shall know then by a line

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I like it
But let me not be fooled again

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Doubt nothing
You do me wrong then, get ye in there private
As I have taught ye; basta

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Work(Exit Memnon.)

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I will do

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Have ye found the cause

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, and the strangest, gentlemen,
That ere I heard of, anon I'll tell ye; Stremon
Be you still near him to affect his fancy
And keep his thoughts off: let the fool and boy
Stay him, they may do some pleasure too; Eumenes
What if he had a wench, an handsome whore brought
Rarely dressed up, and taught to state it?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Well sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: His cause is merely heat: and made believe
It were the Princess mad for him,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I think
'Twere not amiss.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: And let him kiss her

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What else?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: I'll be his bawd an't please you, young and wholesome
I can assure ye he shall have

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Faith let him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A shall, I hope 'twill help him, walk a little
I'll tell you how his case stands, and my project
In which you must be mourners, but by all means
Stir not you from him: Stremon.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.p: On our lives sirExeunt.

sp.speaker: Priestess
sp.l: O you're a precious man; two days in town
And never see your old friend?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Prithee pardon me

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: And in my conscience if I had not sent

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more I would a come; I must

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: I find ye
God a mercy want ye never care for me
But when your slops are empty

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ne'er fear that wench
Shall find good currant coin still; is this the old house?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Have ye forgotten it?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And the door still standing
That goes into the temple?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Still.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The robes to,
That I was wont to shift in here?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: All here still.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O ye tough rogue what troubles have I trotted through?
What fears and frights, every poor mouse a monster
That I heard stir, and every stick I trod on
A sharp sting to my conscience

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: 'Las poor conscience,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And all to liquor thy old boots wench

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Out beast!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: To new carine thy carcase, that's the truth on't
How does thy keel? does it need nailing? A tother
When all thy linen's up: and a more yare?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Fie fie sir

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ne'er stemmed the straits?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: How you talk?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I am old wench,
And talking to an old man is like a stomacher
It keeps his blood warm

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: But; pray tell me

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Any thing

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Where did the boy meet with ye, at a wench sure,
At one end of a wench, a cup of wine sure

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou knowest I am too honest

sp.speaker: Priestess
sp.l: That's your fault
And that the surgeon knows

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Then farewell
I will not fail ye soon

sp.speaker: Priestess
sp.l: Ye shall stay supper
I have sworn ye shall, by this ye shall

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will wench,
But after supper for an hour, my business

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: And but an hour

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No by this kiss, that ended
I will return and all night in thine arms wench

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: No more, I'll take your meaning; come 'tis supper time

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Thou art not well

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Your grace sees more a great deal
Than I feel (Yet I lie) oh brother .

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Mark her,
Is not the quickness of her eye consumed, wench?
The lively red and white?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Nay she is much altered
That on my understanding, all her sleep's lady
Which were as sound and sweet

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Pray do not force me
Good madam where I am not, to be ill,
Conceit's a double sickness; on my faith your highness
Is mere mistaken in meA dead march within of drum and Sagbutts

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am glad on't
Yet this I have ever noted when thou wast thus
It still forerun some strange event: my sister
Died when thou wast thus last: hark hark ho,
What mournful noise is this comes creeping forward,
Still it grows nearer, nearer, do ye hear it?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: It seems some soldier's funeral: see it enters

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What may it mean?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The gods keep ye fair Calis

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This man can speak, and well; a stands and views us
Wooed I were ne'er worse looked upon: how humbly
His eyes are cast now to the earth: pray mark him
And mark how rarely he has ranked his troubles:
See now 'a weeps, they all weep; a sweeter sorrow
I never looked upon nor one that braver
Became his grief; your will with us.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Great ladyPlucks out the cup.
Excellent beauty

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: He speaks handsomely
What a rare rhetorician his grief plays,
That stop was admirable

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: See see thou Princess
Thou great commander of all hearts

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I have found it,
O how my soul shakes:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: See, see the noble heart
Of him that was the noblest: see and glory
Like the proud God himself in what thou hast purchased
Behold the heart of Memnon: does it start ye?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Good gods, what has his wildness done?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Look boldly
You boldly said you durst look wretched woman,
Nay fly not back fair folly, 'tis too late now
Virtue and blooming honour bleed to death here,
Take it the legacy of love bequeathed ye,
Of cruel love, a cruel legacy;
What was the will that wrought it? then can ye weep?
Imbalm it in your truest tears?
If women can weep a truth, or ever sorrow sunk yet
Into the soul of your sex, for 'tis a jewel
The world's worth cannot weigh down,
Take it lady; and with it all (I dare not curse) my sorrows
And may they turn to serpents.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How she looks
Still upon him: see now a tear steals from her

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: But still she keeps her eye firm

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Next read this,
But since I see your spirit somewhat troubled
I'll do it for ye

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.p:
Still she eyes him mainly
Go happy heart for thou shalt lie
Entombed in her for whom I die
Example of her cruelty.
Tell her if she chance to chide
Me for slowness in her pride
That it was for her I died.
If a tear escape her eye
'Tis not for my memory.
But thy rights of obsequy
The altar was my loving breast
My heart the sacrificed beast
And I was myself the priest
Your body was the sacred shrine
Your cruel mind the power divine
Pleased with hearts of men not kine

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Now it pours down

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I like it rarely lady

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How greedily she swallows up his language?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Her eye inhabits on him

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Cruel lady,
Great as your beauty scornful; had your power
But equal poise on all hearts; all hearts perished;
But Cupid has more shafts than one more flames too
And now he must be open eyed, 'tis justice:
Live to enjoy your longing; live and laugh at
The losses and the miseries we suffer;
Live to be spoken when your cruelty
Has cut of all the virtue from this kingdom
Turned honour into earth, and faithful service

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I swear his angers excellent

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Truth and most tried love
Into disdain and downfall,

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Still more pleasing,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Live then I say famous for civil slaughters,
Live and lay out your triumphs, guild your glories
Live and be spoken this is she this lady,
This goodly lady, yet most killing beauty;
This with the two edged eyes, the heart for hardness
Out doing rocks; and coldness, rocks of crystal
This with the swelling soul, more coy of courtship
Then the proud sea is when the shores embrace him
Live till the mothers find ye; read your story
And sow their barren curses on your beauty,
Till those that have enjoyed their loves despise ye,
Till virgins pray against ye, old age find ye
And even as wasted coals glow in their dying
So may the god's reward ye in your ashes:
But you're the sister of my King; more prophecies
Else I should utter of ye true loves and loyal
Bless themselves ever from ye: so I leave ye

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Prithee be angry still young man: good fair sir
Chide me again, what wood this man do pleased,
That in his passions can bewitch souls stay,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Upon my life she loves him

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Pray stay

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I do command ye

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No, ye cannot lady
I have a spell against ye, faith and reason,
Ye are too weak to reach me: I have a heart too,
But not for hawks meat lady

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Even for charity
Leave me not thus afflicted: you can teach me

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: How can you preach that charity to others
That in your own soul are an atheist
Believing neither power nor fear: I trouble ye,
The gods be good unto ye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Lady,She swoons

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: O royal madam, gentlemen for heaven's sake,They come back.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Give her fresh air she comes again: away sirs
And here stand close till we perceive the working

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Ye have undone all

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: So I fear

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: She loves ye

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: And then all hopes lost this way

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Peace she rises

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Now for my purpose fortune

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Where's the gentleman

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Gone madam

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why gone?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Has dispatched his business

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'A came to speak with me
'A did,

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: 'A did not

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: For I had many questions

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: On my faith madam, he
Talked a great while to ye

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou conceivest not.
He talked not as he should do; oh my heart
Away with that sad sight; didst thou ere love me?

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Why do you make that question?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If thou didst
Run run wench, run: nay see how thou stir'st

sp.speaker: Lucip.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If 'twere for any thing to please thyself
Thou wouldst run to'th devil: but I am grown

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Fie lady

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I ask none of your fortunes, nor your loves
None of your bent desires I slack, ye are not
In love with all men, are ye? one for shame
You will leave your honoured mistress? why do ye stare so
What is that ye see about me, tell me;
Lord what am I become? I am not wild sure,
Heaven keep that from me: oh Cleanthe help me
Or I am sunk to death

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ye have offended and mightily, love is incensed against ye
And therefore take my council, to the temple
For that's the speediest physic: before the goddess
Give your repentant prayers: ask her will
And from the oracle attend your sentence
She is mild and merciful

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I will: oh Venus
Even as thou lovest thyself!

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Now for my fortuneExeunt Calis and women.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Why make yourself

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I dare not,
No gentlemen, I dare not be a villain
Though her bright beauty would entice an angel
I will to'th King my last hope: get him a woman
As we before concluded: and as ye pass
Give out the Spartans are in arms; and terrible
And let some letters to that end be feigned too
And sent to you, some poets too, to the general
And let me work: be near him still,

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: We will sir

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Farewell: and pray for all: what 'Ere I will ye
Do it, and hope a fair end

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: The god's speed ye. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Stremon fool, boy, and servants.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: He lies quiet

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Let him lie and as I told ye
Make ready for this show: has divers times
Been calling upon Orpheus to appear
And show the joys: now I will be that Orpheus,
And as I play and sing like beasts and trees
I wooed have you shaped and enter: thou a dog, fool,
I have sent about your suits: the boy a bush,
An ass you, you a lion

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I a dog?
I'll fit you for a dog. Bow wow

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent
Steal in and make no noise

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Bow wow

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Away rogue. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Priestess
sp.l: Good sweet friend be not long

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou think'st each hour ten
Till I be ferreting

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: You know I love ye

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will not be above an hour; let thy robe be ready
And the door be keptKnock.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Who knocks there? Cleanthe knocks within.
Yet more business?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Have ye more pensioners, the Princess woman?
Nay then I'll stay a little, what games a foot now?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Now is the time

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A rank bawd by this hand, too
She grinds a both sides: heigh boys

sp.speaker: Priestess
sp.l: How your brother Syphax?
Loves he the Princess?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Deadly, and you know
He is a gentleman descended nobly.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But a rank knave as ever pissed

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: ●old mother
Here's more gold and some jewels

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Here's no villainy
I am glad I came to'th hearing

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Alas daughter,
What would ye have me do?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hold off ye old whore;
There's more gold coming; all's mine, all

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Do ye shrink now,
Did ye not promise faithfully and told me
Through any danger?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Any I can wade through

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ye shall, and easily the sin not seen neither
Here's for a better stole and a new veil mother
Come ye shall be my friend: if all hit

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Hang me
I'll make ye richer than the goddess.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Say then
I am yours, what must I do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I'th morning
But very early, will the Princess visit
The temple of the goddess, being troubled
With strange things that distract her: from the oracle
(Being strongly too in love) she will demand
The goddess pleasure, and a man to cure her,
That oracle you give: describe my brother
You know him perfectly.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: I have seen him often

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And charge her take the next man she shall meet with
When she comes out; you understand me

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Which shall be he attending; this is all
And easily without suspicion ended,
Nor none dare disobey, 'tis heaven that does it,
And who dares cross it then, or once suspect it?
The venture is most easy.

sp.speaker: Priest
